topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Gokul’s roles across DoorDash, public-company boards, and investing, then asks about his origin story in tech and product.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Amplitude and Flat File.

topics.title: Career serendipity: Cisco to Google AdSense
topics.summary: Gokul shares how Cisco rescinding his offer led him to Google, where curiosity and after-hours exploration helped him join and scale what became AdSense; he emphasizes relationships, inbounds, and paying it forward.

topics.title: Choosing work: passion, customers, and founders
topics.summary: They discuss how passion often emerges after doing the work, why the customer segment matters (SMB/consumer vs enterprise), and how to evaluate founders’ authenticity and mission-orientation versus money-focus.

topics.title: Picking companies: join category leaders and winners
topics.summary: Gokul argues that working at the likely #1 player compounds learning, talent density, and brand halo, often outweighing a bigger title at a weaker company.

topics.title: Best stage to join and market risk
topics.summary: Gokul recommends newer folks often join mid-stage companies (hundreds of employees) with product and channel fit, and cautions that early-stage startups can be especially risky in tougher fundraising markets—so scrutinize financials.

topics.title: Lessons from great companies and founders
topics.summary: He describes different “paths to greatness” (Google technical, Facebook growth, Square design, DoorDash operational), stresses founder authenticity shaping culture, and highlights the need for product remarkability and organic growth.

topics.title: Early product development process and planning cadence
topics.summary: Gokul outlines how planning evolves from weekly (very early) to quarterly and annual as companies scale, recommends simple tooling (often spreadsheets), and explains how product strategy docs emerge once PMs join.

topics.title: Common startup product pitfalls: founder over-control
topics.summary: He warns against founders becoming too tactical and creating a feature factory, advocating instead for empowering teams with problem statements, transparent decision-making, and measuring behavior change.

topics.title: When and how to hire the first PM
topics.summary: Gokul suggests hiring a PM around 8–10 engineers if the founder can’t “feed” the team; he prefers converting a trusted internal engineer/designer/analyst into the first PM, and discusses coaching, evaluation signals, and when to wait.

topics.title: Product org structure: functional vs GM reporting
topics.summary: They discuss when PMs should report to a functional product leader versus a GM, with Gokul recommending a dedicated product manager/leader once there are ~3–5 PMs to ensure coaching and consistent product culture.

topics.title: Hiring leaders: recruit from best-in-class companies
topics.summary: Gokul shares a playbook: identify best-in-class companies for the needed function and customer type, then recruit the strong “lieutenants” (and lieutenants’ lieutenants) rather than the top exec, using org-chart research.

topics.title: Founder time allocation for recruiting and process
topics.summary: He recommends founders spend ~2 hours/day on hiring (outreach plus conversations), and emphasizes that setting the right recruiting process and direction upfront matters more than moving fast in the wrong direction.

topics.title: Titles at startups: avoid premature VP/director inflation
topics.summary: Gokul argues startups should optimize for scope and impact over status, warning that early VP/director titles create contention and retention issues; he distinguishes functional titles from hierarchy-heavy ones.
